anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant does not dispute this position, but he contends that a finding of the Tribunal even on a question of fact would be erroneous in law, if there is no evidence whatsoever to support it or if it is perverse. This question was quite recently considered by this court in Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, and the law was thus stated: The position that emerges on the authorities may thus be summed up: 1. When the point for determination is a pure question of law such as construction of a statute or document of title, the decision of the Tribunal is open to reference to the court under section 66(1). 2. When the point for determination is a mixed question of law and fact, while the finding of the Tribunal on the facts found is final, the decision as to the legal effect of those findings is a question of law which can be reviewed by the court. 3. A finding on a question of fact is open to attack under section 66(1) as erroneous in law when there is no evidence to support it or if it is perverse. When the finding is one of fact, the fact that it is itself an inference from other basic facts will not alter its character as one of facts.

concepts.interpretation: Tribunal fact finding reviewable if no evidence or perverse; pure law, mixed law-fact distinguished

anchor.surface_text: We have considered all the contentions urged on behalf of the appellant at some length. We would like to make it clear that we are not sitting here as a court of appeal on facts. We have examined the record only with a view to see whether there is any misdirection or non-direction... and we have come to the conclusion that there is none, and that the finding of the Tribunal is not therefore open to attack.

anchor.surface_text: Approaching the question from this standpoint, we pose the question, what is the evidence in support of the findings of the Tribunal that the forward contracts which resulted in the profits of Rs. 27,30,094 were made in Bombay and not in Gwalior ? The answer given is that there is the direct testimony of J. R. Pillani and that is supported by circumstantial evidence. Pillani is the proprietor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct testimony of Pillani corroborated by account entries and circumstances; brokers lacked means and credibility; applies no evidence/perversity test from Meenakshi Mills

holdings.text: A finding of fact by Tribunal is open to review only if no evidence supports it or if perverse; here evidence sufficient and not perverse, so no interference under s.66 or Art.136

Commissioner of Income-tax, and the law was thus stated: The position that emerges on the authorities may thus be summed up:

They had nobank accounts and large amounts to the tune of Rs. 30 lakhs are supposed to have been paid to them in cash by J. R. Pillani,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Brokers lacked financial capacity, no prior/subsequent business, no accounts/bank, implausible cash dealings of Rs.30 lakhs, fake ankdas

holdings.text: Every person is entitled to arrange affairs to avoid taxation provided the arrangement is real and genuine, not sham or make-believe

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Kolah argues that there is nothing wrong in business being done in such a way as to escape taxation. No exception can be taken to that statement. Every person is entitled so to arrange his affairs as to avoid taxation but the arrangement must be real and genuine and not a sham or make-believe, and the question now under consideration is whether the contracts with the brokers were genuine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges tax avoidance permissible if genuine; applies to facts finding sham transactions

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 27,30,094 representing profits on forward contracts is taxable under the Act as accrued in British India (Bombay)

anchor.surface_text: Now, the point in dispute in these proceedings is whether the sum of Rs. 27,30,094 received by the appellant as profits in 1942-1943 is taxable under the Act, and that, in turn, depends on whether the forward contracts which resulted in these profits were made at Gwalior as contended by the appellant or at Bombay as held by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-resident taxable if income accrues/arises/receives in taxable territory; contracts and accrual at Bombay per affirmed findings

anchor.surface_text: Approaching the question from this standpoint, we pose the question, what is the evidence in support of the findings of the Tribunal that the forward contracts which resulted in the profits of Rs. 27,30,094 were made in Bombay and not in Gwalior ? The answer given is that there is the direct testimony of J. R. Pillani and that is supported by circumstantial evidence. Pillani is the proprietor
In the result, the appeals fail, and are dismissed. The respondent will get its companyts in Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954. The parties will bear their own companyts in Civil Appeal N

Counsel for the appellant does not dispute this position, but he contends that a finding of the Tribunal even on a question of fact would be erroneous in law, if there is no evidence whatsoever to support it or if it is perverse. This question was quite recently considered by this court in Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, and the law was thus stated: The position that emerges on the authorities may thus be summed up:
In the result, the appeals fail, and are dismissed. The respondent will get its companyts in Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954. The parties will bear their own companyts in Civil Appeal N

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, the question calls for an answer, does any question of law arise on the order of the Tribunal ? It is only if it does, that the decision of the Tribunal will be open to consideration by the court under section 66 of the Act. Stating the same proposition in a different form, if that decision is one of fact turning on the appreciation of evidence,
In the result, the appeals fail, and are dismissed. The respondent will get its companyts in Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954. The parties will bear their own companyts in Civil Appeal N

anchor.surface_text: Now, the facts found by the Income- tax authorities are these The three brokers in whose names the contracts stood were, having regard to their means, not likely to have been thought of for contracts of the magnitude which we have. They had no done business in cotton futures prior to the present contracts no subsequent thereto. They had nobank accounts and large amounts to the tune of Rs. 30 lakhs are supposed to have been paid to them in cash by J. R. Pillani,
In the result, the appeals fail, and are dismissed. The respondent will get its companyts in Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954. The parties will bear their own companyts in Civil Appeal N

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Kolah argues that there is nothing wrong in business being done in such a way as to escape taxation. No exception can be taken to that statement. Every person is entitled so to arrange his affairs as to avoid taxation but the arrangement must be real and genuine and not a sham or make-believe, and the question now under consideration is whether the contracts with the brokers were genuine.
In the result, the appeals fail, and are dismissed. The respondent will get its companyts in Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954. The parties will bear their own companyts in Civil Appeal N
ise on the order of the Tirbunal ? It is only if it does, that the decision of the Tribunal will be open to companysideration by the companyrt under s

anchor.surface_text: Now, the point in dispute in these proceedings is whether the sum of Rs. 27,30,094 received by the appellant as profits in 1942-1943 is taxable under the Act, and that, in turn, depends on whether the forward contracts which resulted in these profits were made at Gwalior as contended by the appellant or at Bombay as held by the Tribunal.
In the result, the appeals fail, and are dismissed. The respondent will get its companyts in Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954. The parties will bear their own companyts in Civil Appeal N
